text:
PEACE
its 2008 a.d.
as much as i would love to be JUST a recording artist, i am
not.-theres a difference
i am a performance artist first - theres a difference.
i write lots of my material with you in mind- there is a
difference
i am very honored that you all care....love or hate (as you call
it) same energy to me.
i am also surprised you dont expect me to fire back- its the best
part.
some cant see us... we are a dying breed.
if you did , you'd also see the humor in my fuckery
and perhaps even understand this hightened ability... to know YOU
so well.
i seriously enjoy you all.
keeps me alert and informed.
this year i turned 36.
my ass and legs have gotten thick.
my children are brave
i feel exquisitely honest... and
since bunches of you are uninformed, i feel compelled.
come on ...
this is therapy for me
we're all (most) on this board for the same reason... so
here is my undivided attention (no "fuck yous"- i cant promise,
however) for a few hours.
ill be logged in the next couple of days.
ill answer any question with in reason.
that way you dont have to guess.
im here.
i hear.
clock is ticking.
lovers grab your hearts...
haters take your marks...
okay.... go.
feed me.

badu

children.text:
to get in my ass, but you know I would have
fired right back at you. In all honesty Erykah, I have been down
since that live performance on Video Soul back in the day, and I
think that was before Baduism even dropped.

I truly love MOST of what you do. I am just at a point where I have
out-grown 98% of hip-hop because most of it is ignorant drivel. I
even make a point of not even listening to a track that uses the N
word (Foreign Exchange gets a pass.... I love that album), but that
is another story. Speaking of Foreign Exchange, Connected was the
last hip-hop album I fell in love with (and yeah, like the other
poster said, you need to get up with Nicolay).

I didn't like WU when it dropped but live performances of Danger, I
Want You and Back In The Day made me appreciate the songs a bit
more. STILL, they were no Mama's Gun. I will more than likely check
out the album, if I hate it I'll tell ya and if i like it, I tell
ya that too. I'm not all hate.

I'm waiting on Edith Funker and Loretta Brown.

what makes you decide to work with a producer?

children.text:
sympathetic vibration.
i am a producer , writter and arranger
i choose like- spirited producers.
i used to listen to dilla's beat tapes, madlib's , karriem's,
sa-ra's 9th jah born etc...
i felt the soul of the fresh choices they made
we vibrate together sympathetically.
theyd always give me beats to vibe to from 1999.
alot the beats are older too lol. yet ageless.
been riding to them forever.

really this internet exchange stuff/ itunes on my mac /ichat
prompted these collabs
for "kahba" (working title).

i put all my beat tapes into itunes and also started using ichat
.
heads were sending me beats.

this quickened everything .
i took my music every where i went now.

(keep in mind i was the chic in 2004 a.d. with an xtra lg tub of 4
inch reels - not rims -every city i went to ...getting held up in
security. )
thus, the name analogue girl.

fast forward to 2006

one day i got on garage band ( a hybrid of logic) and started to
drag the beats from itunes to a track.
then i just layered several vox trx over that beat .
Got about 9 songs in one day...
messing around.
that was the beginning of this particular project.

this made me more independent.
could work quicker and more often.
the kids usually took first seat to creating music.
now it was different.

i chose the beats that i felt had a certain hump to me.

the project really started to pop after i met mike chavaria an
engineer from detroit.
he was working wth jay 'tronic at the time.
i like his fx and ideas.

why these particular producers?
i have so much respect for these cats and what they do.
ive know the process and the wealth of knowlege that they all share
about music and sonics across the board.
scientists and geniuses.
their music collections are extra- ordinary .
we all just click.
same tribe i guess.
i choose all them like this . or something just draws our minds
together.
ie: quest, poyser ,pino , jeff lee , doc gibbs, ron carter,
etc....

FYI : baduism was compiled of carefully selected trx as and 2 live
joints from the roots.

for this project KAHBA , i was def thinking ahead and not
backwards.

you guys are in for an interesting ride.

by the way
the term neo soul was created by Kedar Massenburg the former
manager of D'angelo and former prez of kedar/ motown .
this man signed me in 1995 after hearing baduism in its entireity
minus the roots .
(i brought the roots on board after being given a budget.)
anyway this title NS was originally given to d and i to set us
apart from music in REGULAR radio rotation since we were a little
to the left of that time's sonic sound (1995).

keep in mind my music and d's music sound nothing alike .
Instead what we had in common was an exexcutive who had an ear for
interesting underground talent.

neither d nor i had ever heard this term NS before, nor did we
accept it as who or what we were.
THE NAME TOOK A LIFE OF ITS OWN.

im a theatrical soul singer with a mc background i sing soul music
influenced by everthing.
d has a church backgroud with a heavy soul influence . i think hes
a diamond who would just rather be cole.

its 1:23 am

children.text:
we all have our individual frame of
reference.
& i don't curse celebrities *just* for being
superstars, in fact i may be one of the few
ppl in the world who actually feels sorry
for say...a britney spears. they don't
live the lives that we lead.

first class is HER reality, & if you're in
first class, & mofos tryna treat you like
you're on a buddy pass (which has happened
to me a couple times, only i really was
in first class on a buddy pass :-P) you
have the right to feel some kinda way about
it.

i know *I* did...

there's a lot more going on in that verse
than the first class gripe. i mean how
would any of us (regular folk) feel if
*everybody* was a yes man, & wanted to be
our friend, and we couldn't sift through
the fake/genuine? personally, that would
fuck my head up. i thought her verse was
approp.


Folk in your face, you're a superstar
Niggaz hang around cause of who you are
You get a lot of love cause of what you got
Say they happy for you but they really not
Sell a lot of records and you rollin in
Swoll up in the spot, now you losin friends
All you wanna do is get to where you are
but the label tried to make you compromise your art
You make a million dollars, make a million mo'
First class probably treat you like a nigga po'
You wanna say "Wait!" but you're scared to ask
as your world starts spinning and it's moving fast
Try to stay sane, it's the price of fame
Spending your life trying to numb the pain
You shake that note off and sing a song
Liberate the minds, then you go on home..

we thought it was (LOL!) I had my homeboy in jail congregatin wit
the other incarcerated fellas, we had a slick deputy that was
really down for the cause, pregnant girlfriend coming to visit her
man, and by the end of the song the sly deputy had freed all the
brothers from jai. Mr. Norman was telling us I'm going to show this
to Erykah, we were all so psyched! What do you think of your
experience in the theater dept at GSU? Did you consider an acting
career before you made it in the music industry? I know you're a
hell of an actress, I saw you in the House of D, i enjoyed your
performance, i would love 2 see you in a major role that would give

future goals? Last ques. did you attend booker t for dance or
theater?

children.text:
cause it would seem you got two columns, and
by initiating this line of thought i've been put into the hater
column.

but yes i know what liberation is. and putting it into a song is no
easy task. but i do know is assuming oneself a liberator is a
position of ego, particularly from someone who cannot prove they
have been liberated (shit that sounds snarky, its not meant to be).
i guess its a hard critique this many years later. i'm not
expecting you to go retract the verse etc. seriously, you put
forward the space where i could speak to you candidly, and i shared
a thought i'd always had about a song you were on. because i
question it, doesn't mean i'm against it. i just wondered if you
had thought about it. it would seem not and so i'm glad i put it
out there.

if this makes me a hater in your eyes, that's kind of fucked up,
and actually reinforces my critique about the song. because what is
hate? someone trying to have a true discussion about a serious
topic? what is love? someone who'll go along with whatever you
think because of who you are?

i got love for you e, i speak from a position of love. as human
beings on our own paths to liberation, with the hope that this
discourse might help us both in that regard.

but on a more serious note:

did you vaccinate your children?

and while we're here.... click on the link in the sig

simple.

there is no time or color here.

what ever the music choice ... still expressing the same way

children.text:
First off...I didn't feel "Honey" for a myriad
of reasons....

The beat was okay.....but the thing I've been MISSING from you...is
your words....

You are a thinker...an artist....you give of yourself freely when
inspired....and, more than other artists....one can catch glimpses
of your essence through your words.

I miss that....COHESIVENESS that led to a "Mama's Gun"....the
passion and organization of that project....

Or even the fresh innovation of a "Baduizm"...the way that when you
sang "Otherside of the Game"....you FELT THAT SHIT in your
chest....

Honestly, as an outsider...it just feels like you've been in a
writing rut since those two albums..."Worldwide Underground" had a
few gems...but it wasn't the cover to cover read that your previous
work was.

Now, you gotta understand....I luh you guhl...like...my wife
understands that you are one of the few women I'm leaving her for,
sight unseen!!

But as a result....I EXPECT more out of you than I do these other
cookie cutters...

So where do I fit in....as a fan who wants to let you grow...yet
thirsts for you to strive for the excellence you've shown in the
past?

Real talk, babe....that's the only way I serve it.

Whatever the outcome...keep shining.

Mike

> ... i have grave respect for you and your
critique.
>you gave it.

>did. hhhhhhhhh.

no hurt feelings. and thank you for the exchange.

>NOW
>when i asked you if you knew what liberation was, you
said
>yes but did not define it.

asking someone if they know what liberation is, is not asking
someone to define it. its actually pretty condescending, but a
grain of salt....

>again .
>what is liberation.?

hehehehe.... okay so to understand liberatioin one must understand
the yin to its yang, i'll here represent as the perception of
things inhibiting one from the full potential of their being. in a
word lets say oppression. you can have personal oppression and
social oppression, even global oppression. as such liberation can
be personal, social or even global. even further perhaps racial
(homosapien) liberation, perceptual liberation... blah blah blah.
thing about liberation is that it exists only as a reaction to the
oppression. would someone who's not oppressed need worry about
liberation? and so our ideas about liberation are all theoretical
until we put them to practice, the practice of actually
liberating.

there's stages right, we work through those things that personally
oppress us, opening us up to those things that socially oppress us,
opening up further to what globally oppresses us.

the thing about your verse IMHO, is not that its so much about
personal liberation, but its about personal liberation from
oppression you chose to put yourself into. the trials and
tribulation of fame... that was a choice. and in the scheme of
things you being a person fighting on that social/global level of
liberation, you gotta expect that type of stuff. i'm talking here
about the hatred, the lack of faith in your ability to stay true,
the people that still see you as just another niggress no matter
how much you achieve. those are things you gotta expect signing the
dotted line. and so i don't really want to hear about how hard that
is for you. no offense. i know its hard. i know of many the artist
that has struggled with those issues, but its par for the course.
not something i see as being relevant to the discussion of social
liberation. if you didn't want those things, you shouldn't have
signed on the dotted line, and found another way of achieving your
mission.

>what does it mean to liberate or be liberated ?

at the end of the day only we can free we. we individually must
free ourselves from personal oppressors so that we collectively can
free ourselves from social oppressors, so that we can free
ourselves from global oppressors. you are among many trying to
share the light, but none of you are liberators.

>QUESTION2:
>whats the fundamental diff between my verse and andre's or
big
>boy' s- besides mine being longer?

for one, neither of them are in this exchange. i would have
critique for dre as well (not worrying about what another nigga
think, is not liberation), less so for big boi. that said as i
stated above the thing that set your verse apart is that its about
an oppression you chose to put yourself into.

>what else.

any invalubale resources you found along the way in the education
of your children? books, models etc...

i'd also like to take this time to shout out asoyini - see what
happens when you start talking to artists (e if you're bored you
can search the forum for what this is referencing).

children.text:
I'd like to expound on my thoughts of:

>"The music is the star," says Erykah,
>"I just laid down my vocals and let the
>music breathe while the melodies tell the stories."

and exactly why I feel it is the BIGGEST load of bullshit I've ever
heard.

You simply CANNOT create a masterpiece and then come behind that
with some writer's block type bullshit.

Performance artist or not, you gotta come with the dope shit.

Erykah, please understand that I am not a hater. My comments were
not those designed to applaud any failure - the wackness of
"Worldwide Underground" hurt me two-fold because I kept the faith
that you would come with the same strength of "Mama's Gun", and
THEN I had to defend that fuckery to other people who KNEW I was a
fan/supporter of your work:

"What's up wit ya girl Erykah, tREB? All that "I-I-I-I-I-I"
shit...It sounded like the CD was skippin' nigga!"

Yeah, you never asked me to, but in this business, you KNOW you
have die-hard fans that want to see you win regardless of what
bullshit or greatness you put out. That's how I feel about Mary J.
Blige and Jill Scott. The spirit they exude on their recordings and
in their performances keeps me supporting them regardless of how
their efforts come out.

So, in reply to your comment of "fuck you", instead of the
smart-ass reply of "name a time and place - I'm down to get fucked
by you and start wearing crocheted hats and pants", I'll just say
that I wish you peace and I hope this album is better than
"Worldwide Underground".

I'm ready to accept the fact that you're not consistent enough to
drop another great album like "Mama's Gun". If it turns out that
I'm wrong and your new album IS the shit, I'll GLADLY be the first
person to step up to the bar and put hot sauce on my foot and begin
a chow-down.

Sincerely Yours,

tREBLEFREE


P.S. - Don't forget to bitch-slap all of your yes-men and yes-women
on your way down.

CDs from the stage at a show...

title...

>if you posted something and someone replied that your post

>take that as an acrimonious, fighting words style of

high school education and can read and comprehend at no less than a
10th grade level.

>acrimonious, fighting words style of reply

their opinion with solid reasoning.

"I ain't feelin' it man" while acceptable is REALLY weak.

that "Honey" was not up to par. It's almost like Jesus creates the
heavens and earth, and you ask him for a blessing and he tells you
"Sorry, I'm all out. No soup today."

WTF?

Erykah comes here...what...once a year? If that? I posted that to
start a discussion.

Wanted to let you know I really dig the music.
I get your work more than I get any other artist's work. I get it
without having to think about it. As a fellow Pisces and artist,
your work has left quite an impact on me. "Didn't Cha Know" just
gets me in so many places. Thank you much for that.
So check it, I downloaded a live bootleg of yours, I think it was a
concert you performed on your birthday. I ain't too inclined to be
downloading artist's whole albums, especially cats I like. Way I
figure, I don't generally pay more than $10 for a CD, so that means
I owe you $10. How you figure I can get that ten spot to ya?
Also, do you have any other acting projects lined up? I was a big
fan of yours in Cider House Rules, and I'm still trying to find a
copy of the joint you did with the X-Files guy.
Looking forward to your new work.
Take this positive energy with you into new endeavors.
Peace

been given for you to understand." Saul Williams

children.name: RE: eryKAHBAdu gets THE LESSON

children.text:
earlier in this post i said this:


by the way
the term neo soul was created by Kedar Massenburg the former
manager of D'angelo and former prez of kedar/ motown .
this man signed me in 1995 after hearing baduism in its entireity
minus the roots .
(i brought the roots on board after being given a budget.)
anyway this title NS was originally given to d and i to set us
apart from music in REGULAR radio rotation since we were a little
to the left of that time's sonic sound (1995).

keep in mind my music and d's music sound nothing alike .
Instead what we had in common was an exexcutive who had an ear for
interesting underground talent.

neither d nor i had ever heard this term NS before, nor did we
accept it as who or what we were.
THE NAME TOOK A LIFE OF ITS OWN.

im a theatrical soul singer with a mc background i sing soul music
influenced by everthing.
d has a church backgroud with a heavy soul influence . i think hes
a diamond who would just rather be coal.

its 1:23 am

hope this answers

children.text:
First of all:

Thank you for taking the time to post on this forum.

Second of all:

I have been influenced and inspired by your music both as a
performer and a thinker. I have struggled to negotiate being a
musical artist in an academic setting. Increasingly, I have
grappled with constructions of genre and categories as ways of
trying to explain or represent music, often obscuring the human
realities behind the art. Simultaneously, I struggle constantly
with the dilemmas of trying to produce music that can have a
positive social impact. My personal interest has driven me to
pursue these questions in an academic forum. As an artist that I
respect and admire, one that does not fit easily into conventional
boxes of genre, and whose song messages are both thought-provoking
and socially important, I find you to be a compelling example
through which to explore these subjects. This semester I have
undertaken this exploration in the context of a project questioning
“Neo-soul” as a genre. I give a lot of weight to
artist’s own representations of themselves, and though it is
often necessary, I find it difficult at best to discuss musical
artists without being able to hear many things in their own words.
I have attached my proposal (which I threw together last minute)
and I would really appreciate any comments or ideas that you can
offer on these themes.

Paper Proposal:

Kedar Massenburg, the president of Motown Records from 1997 to
2004, coined the term “Neo-soul” to describe novel
trends emerging from the influences of hip-hop and jazz. The term
has come to represent a large body of work by a diverse group of
artists (Erykah Badu, D’Angelo, Meshell Ndegeocello, Jill
Scott, and others). The movement is characterized by hybridity and
innovative negotiations of genre conventions. Within this movement,
there is a great deal of collective projects and collaboration.
Beneath the broad stroke of coherence uniting artists labeled as
being a part of the “Neo-soul” movement, there is a
great deal of diversity. There are radically different approaches
to tradition, instrumentation, production, and live performance.
Many artists active in this movement are using their music as a
form of social critique and radical intervention in discourses on
race, sexuality, and gender. Collaborating artists often
individually promote strongly contrasting value systems. By
examining different approaches to musical experimentation,
divergent discourses on race, gender, and sexuality, debates over
authenticity and representation, and collaboration I am questioning
the coherence of “Neo-soul” as a movement and the
limits of this categorization.

To explore these questions I will rely on primary sources like
musical pieces, lyrics, liner notes, interviews, and music videos.
In addition I will look at secondary sources that take a
musicological and sociological perspective on this movement, such
as Jeff Chang’s “Can’t Stop Won’t Stop: A
History of the Hip-Hop Generation” and Lori Burn’s
“Disruptive Divas: Feminism, Identity and Popular
Music”. I will be using Okayplayer.com as a source that
represents an innovative blend of artist’s personal accounts
and commentary, news, fan and public perspectives, critical reviews
and discussions. This forum represents an active online community
that connects fans and artists, and it will be an interesting place
to study.
